item.title: Calculus - Series
item.description:
Sequence: 3 - squeeze theorem, con and con theorem, bounded

WHY: Why should we learn Series

  • Making Linear to Discrete.

  • A tool for solving some problems in Physics(TAYLOR POLYNOMIALS, etc.) and some situation.

WHAT: What is Sequence

Sequences: A list of number written in a definite order ${a_n}_{n = 1}^\infty$

Convergence: $\forall \epsilon, \exist N, \forall n > N, |a_n - l| < \epsilon \rArr a_n \rarr l$ OR $\lim_{n \rarr \infty}a_n = L \rArr a_n \rarr L$

E.g. $1/x$: $for \ all \ \epsilon, exist \ N = \frac{1}{\epsilon}, for \ all \ n > N, |a_n - 0| < \epsilon \rArr a_n \ convergent \ to \ 0$

  • Test

    • Bounded by lines: Bounded in both sides + Monotonically increasing or decreasing (the continuous decreasing of distance) = Convergent

      • Bounded in both sides: $\forall n, a_n \leq M$ and $\forall n, a_n \geq N$
      • Monotonically increasing or decreasing: $\forall n, a_n < a_{n+1}$ or $\forall n, a_n > a_{n+1}$

        Note. Identifying between decreasing and non-increasing

    • Bounded by functions (Squeeze Theorem): $a_n \leq b_n \leq c_n \rArr \lim{b_n} = L$

Exercise.

$$ find \ if \ (a) \ a_n = \frac{n!}{n^n} (a > 0), (b) \ a_n = \frac{a^n}{n!} (a > 0), (c) \ a_n = \frac{n^b}{a^n}, (d) \ a_n = \frac{\ln n}{n^b} \ converges $$

$n^n \gg n! \gg a^n \gg n^b \gg \ln{n}$

$$ find \ if \ (a) \ a_n = (1 + \frac{1}{n})^n, (b) \ a_n = (\frac{n}{n+1})^{2n} converges $$ $$ Hint \ 1: known \ (1 - x)^n \geq 1 - nx, (1 + x)^n \geq 1 + nx, x \in [0, 1] $$ $$ Hint \ 2: a_n < b_n = (1 + \frac{1}{n})^{n + 1} $$

  • Usage
    • Continuity and Convergence theorem: $\lim_{x \rarr L}f \exist, \lim_{n \rarr \infty}a_n = L \rArr \lim_{n \rarr \infty}f$
      • $f(x): a_n = f(n), \lim_{x \rarr \infty}f = L \rArr a_n \rarr L$
      • $a_n, b_n, d_n \rarr C \rArr \lim{(a^C + b \cdot d)} = (\lim{a})^C + \lim{b} \cdot \lim{d}$

Arbitrary Sequence

  • Arithmetic sequence

  • Geometric progression

WHAT: What is Series

Series: the sum of the infinite terms from a sequence (limit the $n$ of partial sum $S_n = \sum_{i = 1}^na_n$ to infinity) “The Integral of a Sequence”

Convergence: The divergence or convergence of $S_n \lrArr Series$ diverges or converges

  • Test for Series
    • Direct Test
      • Overall elements (Integral Test): $f(x)$ is continuous and $a_n = f(n)$, $\sum a_n \rarr/\nrightarrow C \lrArr \int_1^\infty f(x)dx \rarr/\nrightarrow C$
      • Adjacent elements (Ratio test): $\lim_{n \rarr \infty}|\frac{a_{n + 1}}{a_n}| = l < 1 \rArr$ absolute converge (prove using geometric series) (> 1 - diverge, = 1 - inconclusive)
      • Single elements (Root Test): $\lim_{n \rarr \infty}\sqrt[n]{|a_n|}$
    • Non-direct Test: Compare with another
      • Limit Comparison test: $\sum a_n, \sum b_n > 0, \lim_{n \rarr \infty}\frac{a_n}{b_n} = C \rArr \sum a_n, \sum b_n$ both di/converge.
      • Comparison test(“Squeeze Theorem”): $\sum a_n, \sum b_n > 0, \sum b_n$ converges and $a_n \leq b_n$ $\rArr$ $\sum a_n$ converges, vice versa (con to di, $\leq$ to $\geq$).
        • Absolutely converge $\sum|a_n|$ is converges (Conditionally = the condition is not plug in absolute value): $0 \leq \sum a_n + \sum|a_n| \leq 2 \sum|a_n|$

Exercise.

$$ \sum{\frac{1}{n^{1+\frac{1}{n}}}} (Hint: \lim_{n \rarr \infty}{n^{\frac{1}{n}}} = 1), \sum{\sin{\frac{1}{n}}} (Hint: \frac{\sin(x)}{x} \leq 1) $$ $$ \sum(1 - \frac{1}{n})^n (Hint: \lim(1 + \frac{1}{n})^n = e), \sum(1 - \frac{1}{n})^{n^2} (Hint: Root \ Test) $$ $$ \sum{\ln(1 + \frac{1}{n})}, \sum \ln(1 + \frac{1}{n^p}) $$

  • Usage

    • $\sum a_n, \sum b_n$ converge, $\sum a_n + \sum b_n = \sum (a_n + b_n)$ and $\sum Ca_n = C \sum a_n$

  • The relationship of Sequence and Series

    • series $\sum_{n = 1}^\infty$ converges $\rArr$ $\lim_{n \rarr \infty}a_n = 0$, or series $\sum_{n = 1}^\infty$ diverges $\rArr$ $\lim_{n \rarr \infty}a_n \neq 0$

      • minus prove: $S_{n} - S_{n - 1}$
      • integral prove

    • $\lim_{n \rarr \infty}a_n = 0$ $\nRightarrow$ series $\sum_{n = 1}^\infty$ converges, e.g. $\sum_{i = 1}^\infty\frac{1}{i} > \ln{(n + 1)}$

Arbitrary Series

  • Geometric Series

  • Alternating Series $\sum(-1)^{n - 1} a_n$

    • $a_{n + 1} \leq a_n, \lim_{n \rarr \infty}a_n = 0 \rArr \sum(-1)^{n - 1} a_n \rarr C$ (decrease + bounded): $S_{2n} = (a_1 - a_2) + (a_3 - a_4) + \ldots +(a_{2n - 1} - a_{2n}) > 0; S_{2n} = a_1 - (a_2 - a_3) - \ldots - a_{2n} < a_1$, then same as $S_{2n + 1} \rArr$ whether n is odd or even, series converges.

    • Alternating Series Estimation Theorem: As the same way as above, we also could derive that $S_{2n} = (a_1 - a_2) + (a_3 - a_4) + \ldots +(a_{2n - 1} - a_{2n}) > (a_1 - a_2) + (a_3 - a_4) + \ldots; S_{2n} = S_{2n} = a_1 - (a_2 - a_3) - \ldots - a_{2n} < a_1 - (a_2 - a_3) - \ldots$

HOW

Power Series

$$ f(x) = \sum c(x - a)^n \text{ is called a power series centered at $a$, domain of $f(x)$ is the set that series converge.} $$

  • only converge at $x = a$
  • converge for all $x \in R$
  • $\exist R > 0, |x - a| < R the series converge, R: radius of convergence$

HOW: Ratio Test + Two sides

Exercise.

$$ \text{Find the domain of } f(x) = \sum \frac{(x - 3)^n}{n} (ANS: [2,4)) $$

HOW: How to apply

if the power series has a convergent radius R > 0, the f(x) is both differentiatable and integrable on the interval (a - R, a + R), and

$$ f\prime(x) = \sum n c_n (x - a)^{n - 1} $$ $$ \int f(x)dx = c + \sum \frac{c_n}{n + 1}(x - a)^{n + 1} $$

E.g.

$$ |x| < 1, \frac{1}{1 - x} = \sum x^n \rArr (\frac{1}{1 - x})^2 = \sum nx^{n - 1} \rArr -\ln{(1 - x)} = \sum \frac{x^{n + 1}}{n + 1} $$ $$ f(x) = \frac{1}{1 - x} \rArr f^{(10)}(x)|_ {x = 0} = 10! $$

WHAT: find if the function could present as series: Taylor Series

$$ c_n = \frac{f^{(n)}(a)}{n!} \rArr f(x) = \sum \frac{f^{(n)}(a)}{n!}(x - a)^n, |x - a| < R, \text{when $a = 0$, it is called maclo… series - unique} $$

E.g.

$$ e^x = \sum \frac{1}{n!}x^n $$

item.title: Calculus - Integral
item.description:
The knowledge marked with * is not necessary in Calculus II

WHY: Why do we want to find out the integral

  • Find out the area
  • Find out some physics parameters

WHAT: What is integral - “Area (with positive and negative)”

Approx. Integral

Equaling space is not necessary

Dividing a function and approx it to separated rectangles, then just calculate the areas of rectangles:

$$ S (\int_a^b{f(x)}dx) = \lim_{n \rarr \infin} \sum_{i = 0}^{n - 1} \Delta x f(x_i) = \lim_{n \rarr \infty}{\sum_{i = 0}^{n - 1}\frac{b - a}{n}f(a + \frac{b - a}{n}i)} $$

Exercise. $$ 1. prove\int_0^1{x^9} = \frac{1}{n}((\frac{1}{n})^9 + (\frac{2}{n})^9 + \ldots + (\frac{n}{n})^9) $$ $$ 2. prove\ln(n + 1) < \sum_{i = 1}^{n}\frac{1}{i} < \ln{n} + 1 $$

  • Riemann integral: left, right, midpoint = $f((x_1 + x_2)/2)$
  • Trapezoidal = (left + right)/2
  • Simpson

$$ y = \frac{(x - x_1)(x - x_2)}{(x_0 - x_1)(x_0 - x_2)}y_0 + \frac{(x - x_2)(x - x_0)}{(x_1 - x_2)(x_1 - x_0)}y_1 + \frac{(x - x_0)(x - x_1)}{(x_2 - x_0)(x_2 - x_1)}y_2 $$ $$ if \ (-h, y_0) (0, y_1) (h, y_2) \rArr \int_{-h}^{h}ydx = \frac{h}{3}(y_0 + 4y_1 + y_2) $$ $$ \rArr S = \frac{h}{3}((y_0 + 4y_1 + y_2) + (y_2 + 4y_3 + y_4) + \ldots + (y_{n - 2} + 4y_{n - 1} + y_n)) (n \ is \ even) $$

Error Bond

$$ Riemann - \frac{K(b - a)^3}{24n^2} (K = |f’’_ {max}(x)|) \newline Trapezoidal - \frac{K(b - a)^3}{12n^2} (K = |f’’_ {max}(x)|) \newline Simpson - \frac{K(b - a)^5}{180n^4} (K = |f^{(4)}_ {max}(x)|) $$

Trans between different variables

$$ \int_{C}^{g(x)}{f(t)}dt, assume \ F(t) = \int{f(t)}dt \rArr \int_{C}^{g(x)}{f(t)}dt = F(g(x)) - F(C) $$ $$ Taking \ derivative \ in \ both \ sides: \frac{d}{dx}{\int_{C}^{g(x)}{f(t)}dt} = \frac{d}{dx}F(g(x)) - \frac{d}{dx}F(C) $$ $$ F’(x) = f(x), F(C) \ is \ constant \rArr F’(g(x)) \cdot g’(x) - 0 = f(g(x)) \cdot g’(x) $$ $$ \therefore \frac{d}{dx}{\int_{C}^{g(x)}{f(t)}dt} = f(g(x)) \cdot g’(x), \frac{d}{dx}{\int_{h(x)}^{g(x)}{f(t)}dt} = f(g(x)) \cdot g’(x) - f(h(x)) \cdot h’(x) $$

HOW: How to integral - Technique

Substitution: If the function combines with its derivative

Rules: $\frac{df}{dx} = \frac{df}{dh} \cdot \frac{dh}{dx}$

  • $\int{F’(g(x)) \cdot g’(x)}{dx}$

$$ u = g(x), du = g’(x) dx \rArr \int{F’(u)}{du} = F(u) + C = F(g(x)) + C $$

Trigonometric function: $\sqrt{1 - x^2}$, $\sqrt{1 + x^2}$, $\sqrt{x^2 - 1}$, $\frac{1}{1 + x^2}$, $\frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}}$

  • $\int{\frac{1}{x(x^2 + 1)}}{dx}$

$$ u = \arctan{x}, du = \frac{1}{x^2 + 1}dx, x = \tan{u} \rArr \int{\frac{1}{\tan{u}}}{du} $$ $$ v = \sin{u}, dv = \cos{u}du \rArr \int{\frac{1}{v}}{dv} = \ln{v} + C = \ln{\sin{u}} + C = \ln{\sin{\arctan{x}} + C} $$

  • $\int{\sec^4{x} \tan^3{x}}{dx}$ $$ \tan{\theta} = \sec^2{\theta} - 1 = \int\sec^2{\theta}d\theta $$

Exercise:

$$ \int{\frac{x}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}}}, \int{\frac{\sqrt{\tan{x}}}{\sin{2x}}}dx, \int_{0}^{3}{\frac{x}{\sqrt[3]{x - 2}}}dx, \int_{e}^{\infty}{\frac{1}{x(\ln^p{x})}}dx, \int{\frac{x^5 - x}{x^8 + 1}}dx $$

Integration by part: If the function combines with a simple function’s derivative

  • Reduce Power: $\int{x \cdot \sin x}dx$

  • Eliminate complex function: $\int{\ln x}dx$

  • *$\int{\frac{1}{\tan^n{x}}}dx$ $$ \sec^2 - \tan^2 = 1 \rArr \int{\frac{\sec^2 - \tan^2}{\tan^n{x}}}dx = \int{\frac{\sec^2{x}}{\tan^n{x}}}dx - \int{\frac{1}{\tan^{n - 2}{x}}}dx $$ $$ \rArr \int{\frac{1}{u^n}}du - \int{\frac{\sec^2 - \tan^2}{\tan^{n - 2}{x}}}dx = \frac{1}{(1 - n)u^{n - 1}} - \int{\frac{\sec^2{x}}{\tan^{n - 2}{x}}}dx + \int{\frac{1}{\tan^{n - 4}{x}}}dx $$ $$ = \frac{1}{(1 - n)u^{n - 1}} - \frac{1}{(3 - n)u^{n - 3}} + \frac{1}{(5 - n)u^{n - 5}} - \frac{1}{(7 - n)u^{n - 7}} + \ldots (\pm \int{\frac{1}{\tan{x}}}dx) + C $$ $$ \rArr \int{\frac{1}{\tan{x}}}dx, v = \sin{x}, dv = \cos{x}dx \rArr \int{\frac{1}{v}}dv = \ln{|v|} + C $$

Exercise:

$$ \int_{-\infty}^{\infty}{\frac{\sin^2{x}}{x^2}}dx \ (Known \ \int_0^{\infty}{\frac{\sin{x}}{x}}dx = \frac{\pi}{2}), \int{\arcsin x \cdot \ln x}dx $$

E.g. Partial Fractions

$$ f(x) = \frac{A(x)}{B(x)} = f_1(x) + \frac{C(x)}{D(x)}, deg(A) >= deg(B) \ or \ deg(C) < deg(D) $$ $$ D(x) = (a_1x+b_1)^{p_1}…(a_ix+b_i)^{p_i}(u_1x^2 + v_1x + w_1)^{r_1}…(u_jx^2 + v_jx + w_j)^{r_j} $$ $$ \rArr \sum_{i, k}\frac{C_{i, k}}{(a_ix+b_i)^{p_k}} + \sum_{j, h}\frac{g_{j, h}x + h_{j, h}}{(u_jx^2 + v_jx + w_j)^{r_h}} $$

then Integral:

  • $\int{\frac{c}{(ax + b)^n}}dx$

$$ \int{\frac{c}{(ax + b)^n}}dx = \frac{c}{a} \cdot \frac{1}{(1 - n)(ax+b)^{n-1}} + C \ or \ = \frac{c}{a} \cdot \ln{|ax + b|} + C \ when \ n = 1 $$

  • $\int{\frac{gx + h}{(ax^2 + bx + c)^n}}dx$

$$ \int{\frac{gx + h}{(ax^2 + bx + c)^n}}dx = \int{\frac{gx + h}{(a(x + \frac{b}{2a})^2 + c - \frac{b^2}{4a})^n}}dx, u = x + \frac{b}{2a} \rArr \int{\frac{iu + j}{(au^2 + k^2)^n}}du $$ $$ (1) $$ $$ \int{\frac{iu}{(au^2+k^2)^n}}du, v = au^2 + k^2, \frac{1}{2a}dv = udu $$ $$ \rArr \frac{i}{2a}\int{\frac{1}{v^n}}dv \rArr \frac{i}{2a} \cdot \frac{1}{(1 - n)(au^2 + k^2)^{n - 1}} + C \ or \ \frac{i}{2a}\ln{|au^2 + k^2|} + C \ when \ n = 1 $$ $$ (2) $$ $$ when \ n = 1: v = \frac{u\sqrt{a}}{k} \rArr \frac{j}{\sqrt{a}}\int{\frac{1}{v^2 + 1}dv} = \frac{j}{\sqrt{a}}\arctan{v} + C $$ $$ *when \ n \neq 1: $$ $$ \int{\frac{1}{(x^2 + 1)^n}}dx, x = \tan{u}, dx = \sec^2{u}du \rArr \int{\frac{1}{\sec^{2n - 2}{u}}}du = \int{\frac{\sec^2{u} - \tan^2{u}}{\sec^{2n - 2}{u}}}du $$ $$ = \int{\frac{\sec^2{u}}{\sec^{2n - 2}{u}}}du - \int{\frac{\tan{u}\sec{u}\tan{u}}{\sec^{2n - 1}{u}}}du, i’ = \frac{\tan{u}\sec{u}}{\sec^{2n - 1}{u}}, i = \frac{-1}{(2n - 2)\sec^{2n - 2}u} $$ $$ \rArr \frac{x}{(2n - 2)(x^2 + 1)^{n - 1}} + \int{\frac{\sec^2{u}}{\sec^{2n - 2}{u}}}du - \int{\frac{sec^2{u}}{(2n - 2)\sec^{2n - 2}{u}}} $$ $$ = \frac{x}{(2n - 2)(x^2 + 1)^{n - 1}} + \frac{2n - 3}{2n - 2}\int{\frac{1}{(x^2 + 1)^{n - 1}}} $$ $$ \int\frac{1}{(ax^2 + b)^n} = \frac{2n - 3}{2b(n - 1)}\int\frac{1}{(ax^2 + b)^{n - 1}}dx + \frac{x}{2b(n - 1)(ax^2 + b)^{n - 1}} $$

Exercise.

$$ \int{ln{(x^2 - x + 3)}}dx, \int{\sec{x}}dx $$

Notice. Approx to limit - Improper Integral: For integral $\int_a^b{f(x)}dx$, when there are some points that are not defined, we use $t$ to approx. the limit of those points

$$ \int_a^b{f(x)}dx = \lim_{t \rarr b}\int_a^t{f(x)}dx $$

HOW: How to apply integral to reality

Rate - Differential Equations

$$ Informal: \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{x}{y} \rArr ydy = xdx \rArr \int{y}dy = \int{x}dx $$ $$ *Formal \ Solution: \frac{d}{dx}{y(t(x))} = \frac{dy}{dt} \cdot \frac{dt}{dx} \lrArr \int{(y(t(x)) \frac{dt}{dx})}dx = \int{(y \frac{dt}{dx})}dx = \frac{y^2}{2} $$

  • Carrying Capacity:

$$ \frac{dN}{dt} = rN(1 - \frac{N}{K}) $$ $$ \rArr \frac{1}{N(K - N)} \frac{dN}{dt} = \frac{1}{K} (\frac{1}{N} + \frac{1}{K - N}) \frac{dN}{dt} = \frac{r}{K} \rArr \int{(\frac{1}{N} + \frac{1}{K - N})\frac{dN}{dt}}dt = \int{r}dt $$ $$ \ln{N} - \ln{(K - N)} = rt \rArr N = \frac{K}{1 + e^{-rt}} $$

$N$ is the population size, $r$ is the intrinsic growth rate, $K$ is the carrying capacity of the local environment, and $dN/dt$, the derivative of $N$ with respect to time $t$, is the rate of change in population with time.

$$ x\frac{d^2y}{dx^2} + 2\frac{dy}{dx} = 0 \rArr \int{(x\frac{d^2y}{dx} + \frac{dy}{dx})}dx = \int{-\frac{dy}{dx}}dx \rArr x\frac{dy}{dx} = -x $$

Exercise.

$$ \frac{dN}{dt} = -aN\ln(bN), *\frac{d^2N}{dt^2} = aN^2\ln(bN) $$

Arc Length

$$ L = \lim_{x_2 \rarr x_1}{\sum{\sqrt{(x_2 - x_1)^2 + (y_2 - y_1)^2}}} = \int{\sqrt{1 + y’^2}}dx $$

Exercise.

$$ Find \ curve \ length \ of \ y = \ln{\sec{x}}, 0 \leq x \leq \pi / 4 $$

Areas

$$ A = \lim_{n \rarr \infty}{\sum_{i = 1}^{n}{\Delta{x}(f(x_i^\star) - g(x_i^\star))}} = \int_{x_1}^{x_2}{(f(x) - g(x))}dx = \int_{y_1}^{y_2}{(f^{-1}(y) - g^{-1}(y))}dy $$

Surface

$$ S = \int{2\pi f(x)\sqrt{1 + f’^2}}dx $$

Volume

$$ V = \int{A(z)}dz $$ $$ Cylindrical \ Shells(y-axis): V = \lim_{\Delta{x} \rarr 0}{\sum{h(x) \cdot \pi ((x + \Delta{x})^2 - x^2)}} $$ $$ = \lim_{\Delta{x} \rarr 0}{\sum{h(x) \cdot \pi (2x \Delta{x} + \Delta^2{x})}} = \int{h(x) 2 \pi x}dx $$

item.title: Calculus - Differentiate
item.description:
WHY

Why should we learn differentiation?

Find the rate: At (when), the rate at which (how) is increasing/decreasing by (what) (unit).

  • Analyzing function
  • Analyzing points

Why a function could be differentiated? - Differentiability

  • Continuous: $\lim_{x \rarr a}{f(x)} = f(a)$ ($\lim_{x \rarr a}{f(x)} = \lim_{x \rarr a^+}{f(x)} = \lim_{x \rarr a^-}{f(x)}$)

    • IVT (Intermediate Value Theorem): If $f(x)$ is continuous on $[a, b]$, then $\exist c \in [a,b], f(c) \in [f(a), f(b)]$
      • MVT (Mean Value Theorem): If $f(x)$ is differentiable on $[a, b]$, then $\exist c, f’(c) = \frac{f(b) - f(a)}{b - a}$
      • EVT (Extreme Value Theorem): If $f(x)$ is continuous on closed interval $[a, b]$, then $\exist c_1, c_2, f_{max}(x) = f(c_1), f_{min}(x) = f(c_2)$
    • Discontinuous points (Discontinuity)
      • Removable ~: $\lim_{x \rarr a}f(x) \neq f(a)$
      • Jump ~: $\lim_{x \rarr a+}f(x) \neq \lim_{x \rarr a-}f(x)$
      • Infinite (Essential) ~: $\lim_{x \rarr a^+}f(x)$ or $\lim_{x \rarr a^-}f(x)$ equals $\pm \infin$

  • Smooth: $\lim_{c \rarr 0^+}{\frac{f(a + c) - f(c)}{c}} = \lim_{c \rarr 0^-}{\frac{f(a + c) - f(c)}{c}}$

  • Limit: L’hospital rule

E.g. $$ \lim_{x \rarr 0^+}{x\ln{x}}, \lim_{x \rarr 0}\frac{\sin{x} - x}{x(\cos{x} - 1)} $$

WHAT: Difference between differentiate and derivative

  • $\frac{dy}{dx}$ differentiate is a method to cut source function to know the tendency
  • $y’(x)$ derivative is that kinds of tendency.

$$ \frac{d}{dx}f(x_1) = f’(x_1) = \lim_{x_2 \rarr x_1}\frac{f(x_2) - f(x_1)}{x_2 - x_1} $$

E.g. Derive: $$ g(x) = \lim_{h \rarr 0}\frac{f(x + h) - \frac{3}{4}f(x + 2h) + \frac{1}{8}f(x + 4h) - \frac{3}{8}f(x)}{h^3} $$

HOW

How to differentiate?

Basic rules

$$ \frac{d}{dx}(f(x) + g(x)) = \frac{d}{dx}f(x) + \frac{d}{dx}g(x) \ or \ (f + g)’ = f’ + g' $$ $$ \frac{d}{dx}(f(x) \cdot g(x)) = \frac{d}{dx}f(x) \cdot g(x) + f(x) \cdot \frac{d}{dx}g(x) \ or \ (f \cdot g)’ = f’ \cdot g + f \cdot g' $$ $$ \frac{d}{dx}f(g(x)) = f’(g(x)) \cdot g’(x) = \frac{d}{dg(x)}f(g(x)) \cdot \frac{d}{dx}g(x) $$ $$ * Inverse \ function: y(x) \lrArr x(y) \rArr \frac{d}{dx}y(x_1) \cdot \frac{d}{dx}x(y_1) = 1 $$

Basic function

$$ \frac{d}{dx}x^n = n \cdot x^{n - 1}, \frac{d}{dx}Constant = 0, \frac{d}{dx}\ln{x} = \frac{1}{x}, \frac{d}{dx}e^x = e^x $$ $$ \frac{d}{dx}\sin{x} = \cos{x}, \frac{d}{dx}\cos{x} = -\sin{x}, \frac{d}{dx}\tan{x} = \frac{1}{\cos^2{x}} = \sec^2{x} $$ $$ \frac{d}{dx}\sin^{-1}{x} = \frac{d}{dx}\arcsin{x} = \frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}}, \frac{d}{dx}\cos^{-1}{x} = -\frac{1}{\sqrt{1 - x^2}}, \frac{d}{dx}\tan^{-1}{x} = \frac{1}{1 + x^2} $$

E.g. Derive $a^x$ and $\log_ax$

E.g. Differential Equations: $x^2 + y^2 = 25$, derive $\frac{d}{dx}y$

How to apply differentiation to reality

Finding Rates

E.g. A particle moves along the x-axis so that at time $t \geq 0$ the position of the particle is given by $x(t) = 0.5t^4 - 1.5t^3 - 2t^2 + 6t - 1$. What is the velocity of the particle at the first instance the particle is at the origin?

E.g. The sides and diagonal of the rectangle are strictly increasing with time. At the instant when two sides of rectangle $x = 4$ and $y = 3$, $\frac{d}{dt}x = \frac{d}{dt}z$ and the rate of the diagonal $z$ has $\frac{d}{dt}z = \frac{d}{dt}y$. Derive the value of $k$.

Curve Sketching

Analyzing function $f(x)$ is increasing/decreasing/constant on $(a, b)$

Analyzing points ($x = a$)

  • Critical point: $f’(x) = 0$ or $\nexists f’(x)$
  • Stationary point: $f’(x) = 0$
  • Relative/Local Extrema: $f’(x) = 0$ and $f’’(x) \neq 0$
  • Inflected point: $f’’(x) = 0$ and $f^{(3)}(x) \neq 0$ - concave upward(>0)/downward(<0)
